citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
4 mice were observed running around the floor of the tamarin enclosure during the inspection. Mice may carry disease
and steal food; this may adversely impact animal welfare. The facility must ensure that the pest control program
effectively eliminates the risk to the animals from these pests.
Correct by 21May2025.

Paint was flaking off and dropping into the interior of the lion enclosure (per the keeper) from edges of skylights, one of
the runners of the guillotine door between individual enclosures was rusted and flaking, and there was evidence of water
leaking from the roof down the wall outside the enclosure. Paint chips may be detrimental to the lion's health, the rusted
door support may not effectively contain an animal or be adequately cleaned, and a leaking roof may contribute to
deterioration of the building and difficulty in maintaining environmental parameters. Correction is in progress.
One wildebeest stall had dirty, broken door flaps at the exit to the outdoor corral. The wildebeest may not have adequate
protection from weather in the stall, and welfare may be adversely affected by the buildup of wastes on the door.
Correction was immediately begun.
The facility must ensure the premises are kept in good repair.
Correct by 21July2025.

The door of the point of care diet refrigerator for the camels is cracked and there is a hole in the bottom, as well as a black
stain that is unremovable around the entire seal. The refrigerator may not adequately be able to maintain temperature or
be sanitized to adequately protect perishable supplies.
An apron used to store training treats for the wild asses was covered in a black material that appeared to be mold.
Contaminated food materials may cause illness when fed to the animals. This apron was removed during the inspection
and discarded.
The facility must ensure that storage for perishable supplies functions as needed to maintain healthful feeds and to
facilitate husbandry practices.
Correct by 21May2025.

The painted dog kennel walls were immediately adjacent to spray foam insulation at the base of the exterior walls of the
building, which were covered in a black, thick material that may be dirt and/or mold or feces. Contaminated surfaces that
the animals are closely adjacent to may contribute to or cause illnesses. The facility must ensure that the premises are
kept clean.
Correct by 06May2025.

The tawny frogmouth enclosure included an unprotected UV light source located so close to the perch that the bird could
access it. Contact with the bulb may injure the animal, and if the light is located too close to the animal it may also be a
source of ocular trauma or irritation. This was corrected the day of the inspection.
The emu co-housed with wallaby and kangaroo had access to unprotected thermostats in the resting boxes and barn.
Emu are inquisitive, and strong, and may remove the covers and potentially be injured by the current in the thermostat.
The facility must ensure the enclosures protect the animals from harm.
Correct by 01May2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
n

narrative:
3.84(d) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
4 mice were observed running around the floor of the tamarin enclosure during the inspection. Mice may carry disease 
and steal food; this may adversely impact animal welfare. The facility must ensure that the pest control program 
effectively eliminates the risk to the animals from these pests.  
 
Correct by 21May2025. 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
Paint was flaking off and dropping into the interior of the lion enclosure (per the keeper) from edges of skylights, one of 
the runners of the guillotine door between individual enclosures was rusted and flaking, and there was evidence of water 
leaking from the roof down the wall outside the enclosure. Paint chips may be detrimental to the lion's health, the rusted 
door support may not effectively contain an animal or be adequately cleaned, and a leaking roof may contribute to 
deterioration of the building and difficulty in maintaining environmental parameters. Correction is in progress. 
 
One wildebeest stall had dirty, broken door flaps at the exit to the outdoor corral. The wildebeest may not have adequate 
protection from weather in the stall, and welfare may be adversely affected by the buildup of wastes on the door. 
Correction was immediately begun. 
 
The facility must ensure the premises are kept in good repair.  
 
Correct by 21July2025. 
3.125(c) 
   
Facilities, general. 
The door of the point of care diet refrigerator for the camels is cracked and there is a hole in the bottom, as well as a black 
stain that is unremovable around the entire seal. The refrigerator may not adequately be able to maintain temperature or

be sanitized to adequately protect perishable supplies.  
An apron used to store training treats for the wild asses was covered in a black material that appeared to be mold. 
Contaminated food materials may cause illness when fed to the animals. This apron was removed during the inspection 
and discarded. 
 
The facility must ensure that storage for perishable supplies functions as needed to maintain healthful feeds and to 
facilitate husbandry practices. 
 
Correct by 21May2025. 
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
The painted dog kennel walls were immediately adjacent to spray foam insulation at the base of the exterior walls of the 
building, which were covered in a black, thick material that may be dirt and/or mold or feces. Contaminated surfaces that 
the animals are closely adjacent to may contribute to or cause illnesses. The facility must ensure that the premises are 
kept clean. 
 
Correct by 06May2025. 
3.153(a)(1)(ii) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The tawny frogmouth enclosure included an unprotected UV light source located so close to the perch that the bird could 
access it. Contact with the bulb may injure the animal, and if the light is located too close to the animal it may also be a 
source of ocular trauma or irritation. This was corrected the day of the inspection. 
 
The emu co-housed with wallaby and kangaroo had access to unprotected thermostats in the resting boxes and barn. 
Emu are inquisitive, and strong, and may remove the covers and potentially be injured by the current in the thermostat.  
The facility must ensure the enclosures protect the animals from harm.  
 
Correct by 01May2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
